The two large hooks have little propellers (the two drops on each hook) attached to them for flying. Beneath is the measuring box, which serves as the body of this flying contraption. The stroke order will cause some problems, so take care with it. [9]

meaning:
a union of two hands, both of which are used at the same time.

Whenever this element appears at the bottom of its relative primitive, the top line is omitted, whether or not there is a horizontal line to replace it.
story: * two hands b Let this primitive represent a union of two hands, both of which are used at the same time. Whenever this element appears at the bottom of its relative primitive, the top line is omitted, whether or not there is a horizontal line to replace it. [4]
Stone . . . two hands. [9]

meaning: valve, petal, braid, speech, dialect, discrimination, dispose of, distinguish, conical cap
story: Elbow . . . two hands. [5]
Bamboo . . . eyes . . . two hands. [14]

Let me share a rather grotesque image to help with this kanji. Imagine taking your two hands and reaching up into someone’s nostrils. Once inside you grab hold of the brain and yank it out. At the end, you would have a picture something like that of this character, the full kanji for nose. [14]
Two hands . . . fiesta. [7]
Tree . . . commandment. [11]
Two hands . . . sabre. [6]
Punish . . . soil. In cases like this, you might find it easier to break the character up into its more basic elements, like this: two hands . . . sabre . . . soil. [9]
* puzzle W Think of this element as a picture puzzle in which the pieces interlock. Its elements: horns . . . two hands. [6]
The sense of the key word is one of joining things together that were previously separate. Its elements: person . . . puzzle. [8]
Any way you count them, there are either too many or too few fingers to see a good pictograph of a hand in this character. But that it is, and so you must. [4]

meaning: a single hand all by itself
story: * Keep to the etymology when using this kanji as a primitive: a single hand all by itself.
Hand . . . eyes. [9]
* fingers − This alternate form of the primitive for hand we shall use to represent finger or fingers. It always appears at the left. [3]
Fingers . . . extremity. [8]
Fingers . . . wrap. [8]
The key word refers to boarding vessels for travel. Its elements are: finger . . . flowers . . . fit together (see frame 254). [12]

meaning: extract, selection, summary, copy, spread thin
story: Fingers . . . a few. [7]
Fingers . . . a whirlwind. [7]
Finger . . . compare. [7]
Finger . . . seduce. [8]
Fingers . . . rocks. [8]
Fingers . . . white. [8]
Finger . . . spike. [5]

meaning: arrest, seize, concerned, adhere to, despite
story: Fingers . . . phrase. [8]

meaning: discard, throw away, abandon, resign, reject, sacrifice
story: Fingers . . . cottage. [11]
Finger . . . mouth . . . dagger. [8]

meaning: challenge, contend for, make love to
story: Fingers . . . portent. [9]
Fingers . . . Buddhist temple. [9]
Finger . . . chariot. [12]

meaning: raise, elevate, hoist, praise, extol, fry in deep fat
story: Fingers . . . piggy bank. [12]

meaning: propose, take along, carry in hand
story: Fingers . . . just so. [12]
onyomi: テイ、 チョウ、 ダイ

story: Finger . . . employee. [13]

meaning: pick up, gather, find, go on foot, ten
story: Fingers . . . fit together. Compare frame 646. [9]
The key word of this frame refers to shouldering a burden of some sort. Its elements are: fingers . . . nightbreak. [8]
Fingers . . . dispose. [8]
Fingers . . . seedling. [11]
Fingers . . . vase . . . woman. [11]

meaning: put up (a notice), put up, hoist, display, hang out, publish, describe
story: Fingers . . . siesta. [11]

meaning: hang, suspend, depend, arrive at, tax, pour
story: Fingers . . . ivy . . . magic wand. [11]
This character simply reverses the direction of the final stroke of hand to produce fur. If you reverse your hand and put its palm down, you will have the side on which fur grows. [4]
Christmas tree . . . fur. [10]

meaning: tail, end, counter for fish, lower slope of mountain
story: Flag . . . fur. [7]
* lock of hair 6 This element is clearly derived from that for fur. By leaving out the second stroke, we get simply a lock of hair. [3]

meaning: consign, requesting, entrusting with, pretend, hint
story: Words . . . lock of hair. [10]

meaning: home, house, residence, our house, my husband
story: House . . . lock of hair. [6]
The pictograph for the ear looks much like that for eye, but note how the stroke order gives it a different look. [6]
Ear . . . heart. It is most rare to have the heart at the right, rather than at the bottom. Take advantage of this fact when you compose your story. [10]
The key word refers to one’s occupation, or position of employment. Its elements: ear . . . kazoo. [18]
Ear . . . mouth . . . king. [13]

meaning: daring, brave, bold, sad, tragic, pitiful
story: Spike . . . ear . . . taskmaster. [12]
Ear . . . crotch. [8]

meaning: purport, gist, elegance, interest, proceed to, tend, become
story: Run . . . take. [15]
Sun . . . take. [12]
Finger . . . utmost. This character is used for taking photographs. Not how, conveniently, the element for “take” is hidden in it. [15]
This character, a pictographic representation of the heart, is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet. [4]

meaning: it appears beneath or to the right of its relative primitive and means the physical organ of the heart.
story: * as a primitive, it can take three forms, to which we shall assign three distinct meanings. * In its kanji-form, it appears beneath or to the right of its relative primitive and means the physical organ of the heart.
Perish . . . heart. [7]

meaning: endure, bear, put up with, conceal, secrete, spy, sneak
story: Blade . . . heart. Endure here means long-suffering patience. [7]
Snake . . . heart. [7]

meaning: intention, plan, resolve, aspire, motive, hopes, shilling
story: Samurai . . . heart. [7]
In the middle of a . . . heart. [8]
Brains . . . heart. [9]

meaning: grace, kindness, goodness, favour, mercy, blessing, benefit
story: Take grace in its sense of a favour freely bestowed, not in its meaning of charming manners or fluid movement. The primitives: cause . . . heart. [10]

meaning: apply, answer, yes, OK, reply, accept
story: Cave . . . heart. The sense of the key word here is of something appropriate that fills a particular need, and hence “applies.” [7]
To distinguish this kanji from that of the previous frame, focus on the sense of the “con-” in the word “concept.” Its elements are: inter. . . heart. [13]
Ten . . . fields (or: needle . . . brains) . . . heart. [10]
Craft . . . mediocre . . . heart. [10]
Mouths . . . marching . . . heart. [13]

meaning: melancholy, grieve, lament, be anxious, sad, unhappy
story: Head . . . crown . . . heart . . . walking legs. Two things merit mention here. First, the doubling-up of the last stroke of head with the top of the crown serves to make the whole more aesthetically beautiful. It happens so rarely that the exceptions are easily learned. Second, try to make a single image out of the four elements. (Religious statuary of melancholy figures should offer plenty of suggestions.) [15]

House . . . head . . . dagger. Immediately we get another instance of a very odd exception. Notice how the final stroke of the head is lenghthened, giving the final two strokes a chance to stretch out and make room for the dagger that fits in beneath. [14]
State of mind . . . perish. [6]
State of mind . . . devil. [10]
State of mind . . . span. [9]
To keep this character distinct from others of similar connotation, one need only think of the Prophet Jeremiah whose poetry gave an eminence to the state of mind we call lamentation. [11]
State of mind . . . linen. [8]
State of mind . . . every (see frame 458). [9]
State of mind . . . increase. [13]

meaning: accustomed, get used to, become experienced
story: State of mind . . . pierce. [14]
State of mind . . . left (i.e. “sinister”) . . . flesh. [12]
State of mind . . . truth. [13]
State of mind . . . emotion. Hint: the etymology of “remorse” indicates a memory that returns again and again to “bite at” one’s conscience and disturb one’s peace of mind. [16]

meaning: yearn after, long for, aspire to, admire, adore
onyomi: ショウ、 トウ、 ドウ

story: State of mind . . . idea. [16]

meaning: pining, yearn for, love dearly, adore
story: Graveyard . . . valentine. Note carefully the stroke order of the valentine primitive. [14]

meaning: annexed, accompany, marry, suit, meet, satisfy, attach, append, garnish, imitate
story: Water . . . heavens . . . valentine. [11]

First note the stroke order of this character, which did not really evolve from the heart, even though we take it that way. If one takes it as a pictograph “dividing” the heart in half, then one has one of those invariably true bits of human anatomy: the fact that each heart is divided into two halves. [5]

meaning: ooze, flow, soak in, penetrate, secrete
story: Water . . . the invariably divided heart. [8]
House . . . invariably . . . mountain. [11]
House . . . invariably . . . insect. [14]

meaning: leg, foot, be sufficient, counter for pairs of footwear

Person . . . leg. [9]
Hand . . . leg. [10]
Wooden leg . . . gigantic. [12]

meaning: hop, leap up, spring, jerk, prance, buck, splash, sputter, snap
story: Wooden leg . . . portent. [13]
Wooden leg . . . feathers . . . turkey. [21]

meaning: tread, step on, trample, practice, carry through
story: Wooden leg . . . parade float. [13]
Wooden leg . . . Main point. [15]
Legs . . . Take position. [19]

meaning: step, trample, carry through, appraise, evade payment
story: The meaning of this character is virtually identical with that of the last frame. Be sure to come up with distinct connotations suggested by phrases in which each is commonly used. Wooden leg . . . water . . . sun. [15]
Wooden leg . . . each. [13]
Rain . . . path. [21]

This kanji and primitive refer to the part of the body composed of the bones and their joints. The top part of the kanji, terminating in the element for crown, is a pictograph of a bone joint. I leave it to you to put the pieces together, so to speak. [10]
Skeleton . . . possess . . . road. [19]
Water . . . skeleton. [13]
* jawbone ‚ The meaning of this primitive is taken from the combination of “the joint” above and the mouth in the cowl below. [9]
Altar . . . jawbone. [13]
Water . . . jawbone. [12]
Water . . . jawbone. [12]
Jawbone . . . road. [12]

Whatever one is particularly adept at—one’s special “genius”—one can do very easily, “with one finger” as the phrase goes. This kanji is a pictograph of that one finger. Note how its distinctive form is created by writing the final stroke of the element for fingers backwards. [3]

* + , * The primitive meaning, genie, derives from the roots of the word genius. Use the genie out in the open when the primitive appears to the right of or below its relative primitive; in that case it also keeps its same form. At the left, the form is altered to c, and the meaning becomes a genie in the bottle. 2
Clam . . . genie. [10]

meaning: lumber, log, timber, wood, materials, ingredients, talent
story: Tree . . . genie. [7]
Genie in the bottle . . . soil. [6]

meaning: exist, suppose, be aware of, believe, feel
story: Genie in the bottle . . . a child. Hint: focus on the key word’s connotation of “make believe”. [6]

meaning: length, ten shaku, measure, Mr., Ms., height, stature, all (one has), only, that's all, merely
story: The length whose measure this kanji depicts extends from the tip of one hand to the tip of the other with arms at full length. Notice the final stroke, which cuts across the vertical second stroke to distinguish it from large (frame 107). [3]
A mouth . . . tucked under the arm. [5]
One . . . mouth . . . tucked under the arm. [6]
The implication behind the meaning of grow late is that things are changing in the same way that the day turns into night. The elements: ceiling . . . sun . . . tucked under the arm. [7]

meaning: for the most part, close up, flower stem

story: Rocks . . . grow late. [12]
* stamp A This character is a kind of pictograph of a stamp that may best be imagined as a postage stamp to distinguish it from other stamp-like things to come up later. [2]
The left primitive is a union of a horse and footprint. To the right, the stamp. [9]
Line . . . wholesale. [12]
Flesh . . . stamp . . . crotch. Note how the stamp is stretched out here. [8]

meaning: fate, command, decree, destiny, life, appoint
story: This character connotes life in general, but also the particular life that is fated one by virtue of the distinctive character with which one is born. Its elements are: fit . . . stamp. The bottom portion of fit is nudged to the left in order to make room for the stamp. [8]

meaning: traffic, pass through, avenue, commute, counter for letters, notes, documents, etc.
story: Chop-seal . . . utilize . . . road. By combining the first two primitives into a single image, you will be able to use that image in a few instances later, one of which comes immediately. [10]
Wooden leg . . . chop-seal . . . utilize. [14]

meaning: courage, cheer up, be in high spirits, bravery, heroism
story: Chop-seal . . . male. [9]
Water . . . ice. [12]
Meeting . . . chop-seal. [5]
Rain . . . orders. [12]
This character is used to express the years of one’s age. Its elements: teeth . . . orders. [17]
Ice . . . orders. [7]
Orders . . . head. [14]
Gold . . . orders. [13]

* receipt Š This primitive element is actually the mirror-image of that for stamp, but since Japanese does not permit a stroke to go to the left and bottom in one swoop, the visual similarity is not perfectly clear. If you play with the idea with pen and paper, its logic will become obvious. [3]

meaning: sign of the hare or rabbit, fourth sign of Chinese zodiac, 5-7AM, east
story: Receipt . . . stamp. [6]
Tree . . . receipt . . . stamp. [9]
Receipt . . . stamp . . . and a drop in each side to represent a little smear of egg yolk. The third stroke is drawn slightly higher to close the egg up tightly and keep the yoke inside. [7]

meaning: repress, well, now, in the first place, push, shove, press, seal, do in spite of
story: Fingers . . . box . . . stamps. [7]

meaning: face-up, look up, depend, seek, respect, rever, drink, take
story: This character is used both for lying on one’s back faceup, and for looking up to someone with respect and awe. Its elements: person . . . box . . . stamps. [6]
Box . . . stamps . . . road. [7]
Receipt . . . dagger . . . rice field. [10]
Receipt . . . dagger . . . shells. Though the meanings are related, do not confuse with make a deal (frame 439) or wholesale (frame 1397). [12]
* staples ‹ This primitive represents a number of small staples, like the kind commonly used in an office and at school. [4]

meaning: stamp, seal, mark, imprint, symbol, emblem, trademark, evidence, souvenir, India
story: At last we come to the general character meaning stamp. Its elements: staples . . . stamp. [6]

The kanji connoting rank or class shows us a new element on the left: the familiar primitive for staples with an additional stroke cutting through the vertical stroke. It is easiest in these cases to make a primitive related to what we already know. Hence, we call it a staple gun. To the right, missile. [9]
Metal . . . grade. [17]
Water . . . morter . . . . tail feathers [15]

Let this character represent a wheel of fortune that has been tampered with. On both sides you see the staples separating one number’s slot from the next, and between them the character for the same—indicating that it has been fixed to repeat the same number. Beneath is the primitive for a tool, which refers to the wheel itself. All together, a fitting symbol for entertainment, especially if you are the owner of the wheel. [16]

meaning: break, destroy, censure, be chipped, be scratched, be broken, be ruined
story: Morter . . . ground . . . . Missile [13]
